metadata.case_name: New Era Agencies Pvt. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City

facts.text: Assessee company incorporated on May 6, 1943, with paid up capital of Rs. 20 lakhs, promoted by Morarka Group and Bubna Group.
Apollo Mills Co. Ltd. had capital of Rs. 50 lakhs divided into 25 lakhs shares of Rs. 2 each; Sassoons held 19,76,000 shares and were Managing Agents.

Agreement dated April 27, 1943, between promoters of assessee and Sassoons: transfer Managing Agency for Rs. 12-1/2 lakhs and 19,76,000 shares at Rs. 4-4-0 per share (total Rs. 83,98,000); clause 3 required simultaneous completion.
During negotiations before April 27, 1943 agreement, promoters entered arrangement with share brokers for sale of large portion of 19,76,000 shares.
Tripartite agreement dated November 1, 1943, between Sassoons, promoters as Confirming Parties, and assessee as Assignees: transferred Managing Agency and share certificates with blank transfers.
Sold 10,00,000 shares to brokers at prices from Rs. 5-8-0 to Rs. 5-13-0; brokers resold in smaller lots.
1,20,000 shares transferred to 13 nominees of Morarka Group at cost price.
Total 13,74,000 shares sold, resulting in excess of Rs. 16,52,600 over purchase price; remaining shares retained.
Income-tax Officer held Rs. 16,52,600 not profit and not taxable.
Case referred to Investigation Commission; report dated November 9, 1949, in Case No. 406A: directed assessment under Indian Income-tax Act for 1945-46 and Excess Profits Tax Act.
Commissioner of Income-tax referred question to Bombay High Court on May 1, 1951, under s. 85 of Taxation on Income (Investigation Commission) Act, 1947.
Question referred: Whether Rs. 16,52,600 excess was profit taxable or capital appreciation/casual receipt exempt u/s 4(3)(vii) IT Act.
High Court reformulated question: Whether materials justify finding that purchase and sale of 13,74,000 shares was adventure in nature of trade? Answered affirmatively.
Assessee's Notice of Motion on November 8, 1952, to refer other questions dismissed by High Court as not arising or time-barred.

Investigation Commission found: intention to retain 6 lakhs shares for managing agency effectiveness, sell 13 lakhs odd; negotiations with brokers started early; necessary to sell to pay Sassoons given capital Rs. 20 lakhs.

legal_issues.text: Whether the transaction of purchase and sale of 13,74,000 shares was an adventure in the nature of trade, making Rs. 16,52,600 taxable profit.
Whether the question could be reframed by High Court.
Whether constitutional question under Art. 14 could be raised.

petitioner_arguments.text: Dominant intention was to obtain Managing Agency; forced to buy whole block as Sassoons insisted; sold due to insufficient capital (Rs. 20 lakhs) to complete agreement.
Memorandum of Association showed holding company, not dealing in shares as object.
Rs. 16,52,600 was capital receipt, not profit from adventure in trade.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ramnarain Sons Pvt. Ltd. v. CIT; Kishan Prasad Co. v. CIT

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in reframing question; other questions should be referred; discrimination under Art. 14.

respondent_arguments.text: Intention from outset to sell 13 lakhs shares; distinction between retained and sold shares; necessary to sell to finance purchase.
Transaction had all attributes of adventure in nature of trade.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Venkataswami Naidu v. CIT; Edwards v. Bairstow

court_reasoning.text: To determine adventure in nature of trade, consider intention of assessee in light of legal requirements of trade/business; inference from facts is mixed question of law and fact.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legal effect of facts found by Commission is question of law.

court_reasoning.text: Transaction inescapably commercial: promoters arranged sales before agreement; insufficient capital necessitated sale to complete purchase and secure agency.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Never intended to retain whole block; divided shares themselves.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished Ramnarain Sons: there shares bought above market for agency, no separate price; here separate valuations, intention to sell clear.
Distinguished Kishan Prasad: no intention to resell from inception.
Totality of circumstances: promoters put Rs. 20 lakhs, floated company to acquire agency and shares beyond capacity; arranged sales during negotiations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: All attributes of adventure in trade.

court_reasoning.text: SC exercises advisory jurisdiction like HC; no new questions like Art. 14; Notice of Motion rightly dismissed.

holdings.text: Purchase and sale of 13,74,000 shares was adventure in nature of trade; Rs. 16,52,600 taxable profit.
High Court reframing not erroneous; answer affirmative even to original question.
Art. 14 question not raisable in advisory jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ms. Ramnarain Sons Pvt. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Shares bought above market for agency; intention not trade; different from present separate pricing and sale intent.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tata Hydro-Electric Agencies, Bombay v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Commission for acquiring agency, not for producing profits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ms. Motiram Nandram
precedents_cited.relevance: Expenditure for securing agency to carry on business.
Isolated transaction not in nature of trade.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Inland Revenue v. Reinhold
Saroj Kumar Mazumdar v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: No clear evidence of intent to sell at profit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kishan Prasad Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: No intention to resell; capital investment for agency.
Facts showed adventure in trade despite Commissioners' finding.

precedents_cited.case_name: G. Venkataswami Naidu Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Totality of circumstances determines character; not counting factors.

statutes_cited.name: Taxation on Income (Investigation Commission) Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference of question to High Court; advisory jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Taxability of profits; casual receipts exempt; time for reference.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Discrimination; not raisable in advisory jurisdiction.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court and Investigation Commission's finding that the purchase and sale of 13,74,000 shares was an adventure in the nature of trade, making Rs. 16,52,600 taxable profits; dismissed appeal; confirmed dismissal of Notice of Motion.

key_quotes.text: "In considering the question whether the transaction was or was not an adventure in the nature of trade, the court had to take into consideration the intention of the assessee keeping in view the legal requirements which are associated with the concept of trade or business."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key test for determining nature of transaction.

key_quotes.text: "The transaction that consisted of buying the Managing Agency of the Mill Company and the block of shares held by Sassoons was inescapably one of a commercial nature and had all the attributes of an adventure in the nature of trade."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The jurisdiction which this Court would exercise in appeal was of the same character that a High Court would exercise."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits scope; bars new questions like Art. 14.
